awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Stochasticity and Cryoconite Community Assembly and Function
awd_abstract_narration:
Cryoconite holes are pockets of life completely encased in otherwise barren glacial ice.  These pockets of life form when dust blown onto the ice melts a small, largely isolated hole that can function as its own tiny ecosystem.  This dust can contain microorganisms such as bacteria, algae, or microscopic animals. The microorganisms within the hole interact and carry out functions typical of a larger ecosystem, such as a forest. Cryoconite holes are especially important in extreme cold environments such as the Antarctic Dry Valleys, where they function as repositories of life.  Because cryoconite holes are mostly enclosed and persist for years, they can be tracked over time to test fundamental scientific questions about how communities of interacting organisms develop to become fully functioning ecosystems.  This project will sample existing and experimentally created cryoconite holes to understand how these ecosystems develop and to what degree random processes (such as which organisms get there first) affect the final community composition and functioning.  The results will not only improve our understanding of how microbial communities assemble and affect the functioning of microecosystems such as cryoconite holes, but also how the processes of community assembly affect functioning of larger ecosystems, such as forests.  A better understanding of community establishment, development, and response to abiotic factors are essential to forecasting ecological responses to environmental change.

It is essential to unravel the links between community assembly, biodiversity, and nutrient cycling across numerous ecosystems because these are critical factors determining ecological responses to environmental change. The unique, largely isolated nature of cryoconite holes provides an experimental system that will advance fundamental understanding of the processes (e.g., stochastic dynamics such as dispersal limitation, assembly order, and ecological drift) driving community assembly. This project will use a field sampling campaign and a number of manipulative experiments to test a hypothesis that unites theory in community and ecosystem ecology: the degree to which stochastic processes guide microbial community assembly and affects regional patterns in biodiversity and ecosystem processes. Cryoconite holes will be sampled to compare community composition, environmental factors, and ecosystem functioning between hydrologically connected and isolated holes. New cryoconite holes will also be constructed and monitored over the course of two growing seasons to specifically alter assembly order and community size, thereby pairing a unique manipulative experiment with field surveys to address questions with relevance to the Antarctic and beyond. Amplicon sequencing, metagenomics, microscopy, sensitive environmental chemistry methods, and photosynthesis and respiration measurements will be used to test a series of sub-hypotheses that relate stochasticity to patterns in regional biodiversity, heterogeneity in environmental factors, and ecosystem processes.

por.por_cntn:
This project is about microbial community dynamics, meaning how do small, relatively simple life forms (microbes) interact with each other in the same environment. The question driving this research is, if we make up a community composed of different kinds (species) of microbes, will the resulting diversity of the community and its biochemistry be the same no matter which species was introduced first. Although this question sounds arcane, it reflects on processes in ecosystems generally. For example, if one wanted to reestablish a forest community, does it matter if you add this animal first or that animal first? Forest studies of these kind are difficult and complex to manage and takes decades to complete but working at the microbial level, allow many one to make many experiments over a relatively short period to test the concept of differences in the community due to order of species introduction.

Our study tests this idea in cryoconite holes found in Antarctica. Cryoconite holes are naturally formed melt holes in the icy surface of a glacier. Sediment blown on the glacier collects in slight depressions forming patches 0on the ice surface. Because the sun heats the dark sediment more effectively than the brighter reflective ice, the sediment temperatures can warm enough to melt the ice beneath, lowering the sediment into the ice. As the sediment lowers it forms a cylindrical hole of water perhaps a foot deep. Typically, the sediment also contains microbes that thrive in the hole water. Although such holes are common to all glaciers where melt occurs, in our study region of Antarctica, they form a frozen cap preventing air or surface melt on the glacier from getting into the trapped subsurface hole water. The water freezes in winter, then melts out again the following summer, but still under the ice cap. This little ecosystem of microbial life is entombed in the ice.

This situation is ideal for our microbial experiments because we can place lots of sediment patches on the glaciers surface each inoculated with different microbial life and let them melt into the ice and freeze-over trapping them and allowing them to develop a stable community over time. The following spring, before the subsurface ice melts, the refrozen cryoconite hole can be drilled and the ice sampled to measure the diversity and biochemistry of the community. In addition to understanding microbial community dynamics, the cryoconite holes may be important analogs for life on other icy planets. They may also help us understand how life on Earth survived “Snowball” Earth, 650 million years ago when the Earth may have been entirely frozen.

Results from the biological work to date showed that experimentally created cryoconite holes became indistinguishable from natural ones over the course of the summer. Furthermore, the microbial population changed in diversity similar to that found in natural holes. One consequence of having an ice lid, is that the microbial system is limited by the lack of phosphorous, a key nutrient for organisms.

My part of the project was the physical hydrology and glacier processes. I helped with strategies of hole formation, detecting when the holes begin to melt, monitoring the temperature and changing chemistry of the hole waters over the summer, and when they begin to start freezing. From a hydrological point of view, these holes create much of the meltwater on these glaciers, some of which drain and flow off the glacier. They represent a transition state between cold, non-melting, glacier ice and relatively warm melting ice, like most glaciers in the temperate latitudes. The former doesn’t melt and the latter melts lots. Understanding this transition stage helps modelers understand how these cold glaciers warm up and begin to melt. That meltwater ends up raising global sea levels.

Early in the season, the temperature of the cryoconite in the refrozen hole follows the daily changes in solar radiation clearly showing it is heated by the sun rather than air temperatures. Later in the summer, when air temperatures warm to a few degrees below freezing, the temperature of the cryoconite becomes warm enough to melt the surrounding ice and the ice begins to melt out from within. If snow accumulates on the ice the holes begin to freeze again. Under snow-free conditions, the holes did not all deepen from year to year. Local variations in the ice, and sediment depth, caused some holes to deepen more in than others in any given summer. Thus, water production from the holes also varies across the glacier and season to season.
